slide.title: What is keynote?
slide.bullet: Keynote is tool to create presentations from text files.
The idea is to be able to edit presentations with a regular text editor.

slide.title: This is a code slide
slide.bullet: This is a sample of code:

slide.title: Features
slide.bullet: Syntax highlighting for pieces of code.
Presentations can be viewed over the web using a regular browser with no plugins.
Presentations are a lot sexier than pdf or powerpoint
Presentations are simple to create, no need for big software
Presentations look good on any screen size because of layout manager used within keynote
Presentations stay small in size

slide.title: Why should I use keynote ?
slide.bullet: You want to keep the source of your presentation in source control.
You hate using a wysiwyg editor.
It allows many people to work on the same presentation at the same time and resolve their differences using common tools.
It separates content and presentation.
It forces same look and feel on all of your presentations.
Presentations look better because they are generated by machine and all the text is well aligned.
You can convert the content to many types: pdf, odp, html and more.

slide.bullet: You can use any editor you like (I use vim)

slide.title: Comparison to other solutions
slide.bullet: DocBook is nice but not tuned to slides.

slide.title: Browser support
slide.bullet: keynote is developed on a recent version of chrome and that is the browser that it supports the best
Latest versions of chrome and firefox are supported.
Other browsers will be supported only if users report and help out with bugs.
keynote.js does use jQuery at the bottom layer and browser independant coding and so it is quite portable and bug fixes should not be hard
Browser support is an issue which is not of equal importance to all users
This means that if you are a person doing presentations you have more incentive to work with keynote even before it reaches maturity with all browsers

slide.title: Keynote philosophy
slide.bullet: Content should always be in text files.
Customisation of graphics and look and feel are not very important.
Separation of content and presentation is important.
Simplicity in UI is a good thing.
Big software is evil. Lots of small pieces of software is good.
Mark is always right, especially when he is dead wrong.
